hero.title: How the Neighborhood Trajectory Score Works
hero.intro_1: Every neighborhood in Sweden receives a score from 0 to 100 that reflects its current conditions and likely trajectory over the coming years. The score combines official government data across multiple dimensions — economics, education, safety, and financial stability — into a single number designed to help you understand where an area stands and where it’s heading.
hero.intro_2: We built this because no tool like it exists in Sweden. Hemnet shows you listings. Booli shows you prices. We show you why prices move.

score_glance.title: The Score at a Glance
score_glance.normalization_desc: Percentile ranking across all 6,160 areas in Sweden
score_glance.explanation: Each area is compared against every other area in Sweden using percentile ranking — meaning a score of 75 tells you this neighborhood outperforms roughly 75% of all areas nationwide on the factors we measure.

score_meaning.title: What the Score Means
score_meaning.disclaimer: A score is not a verdict — it’s a starting point. A score of 35 doesn’t mean you shouldn’t buy there; it means you should understand why it scores that way before you do. The factor breakdown for each area (available when you click on the map) shows exactly which dimensions are strong and which are weak, so you can make your own judgment.

how_we_build.title: How We Build the Score
how_we_build.relative_desc: We don’t score areas on an abstract scale. Every area is ranked against every other area in Sweden. A score of 73 means this area outperforms 73% of all neighborhoods in the country on the factors we measure. This makes scores directly comparable — whether you’re looking at central Stockholm or rural Norrland.
how_we_build.public_title: All data is public and official.
how_we_build.public_desc: Every input to our model comes from Swedish government agencies: SCB, Skolverket, BRÅ, Kronofogden, and Polisen. We don’t use proprietary data, surveys of our own, or user-submitted reviews. This means our scores are reproducible, auditable, and grounded in the same statistics that policymakers rely on.
how_we_build.matters_title: We measure what matters for real estate.
how_we_build.matters_desc: Not every statistic matters equally for property values. We focus on the factors that research and market evidence show actually drive where people want to live and what they’re willing to pay. The weighting of each factor in our model is based on its demonstrated relationship with real estate outcomes in the Swedish market.
how_we_build.aggregate_desc: All our inputs are aggregate statistics — averages, rates, and percentages across entire areas. We do not access, store, or process any data about individual people. This is a deliberate design choice, both for legal compliance and because aggregate patterns are what drive neighborhood-level trends.
how_we_build.updates_title: The score updates as new data becomes available.
how_we_build.updates_desc: Government agencies publish new data on different schedules — some annually, some quarterly. When new data arrives, we re-run the model and the map updates. The “last updated” date for each data source is visible in the area detail view.
how_we_build.boundaries_desc: Government statistics are published for defined geographic areas — but reality doesn’t stop at a boundary line. A street that separates two statistical areas doesn’t create a wall between them. That’s why our map defaults to a hexagonal grid rather than showing raw administrative boundaries. Each hexagon blends data from the statistical areas it touches, creating smooth, gradual transitions that reflect how neighborhoods actually work. You can switch to the traditional boundary view at any time, but the hexagonal layer gives you a more honest picture of how conditions shift across the landscape.

cta.title: Ready to explore?
cta.subtitle: Go back to the map and click any area in Sweden to see its score, factor breakdown, and school details.
